articles.headline: ABC News President to Be Top Disney TV Executive
articles.snippet: Ben Sherwood, who will head the ABC Television Group, has drawn attention for his work at the news operation, notably the rise of “Good Morning America.”
articles.abstract: Ben Sherwood, who will head the ABC Television Group, has drawn attention for his work at the news operation, notably the rise of “Good Morning America.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The Walt Disney Company acted quickly to put a new top executive in place at its ABC Television Group, naming Ben Sherwood on Monday to succeed Anne M. Sweeney, who announced her resignation two weeks ago.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Jury Says 5 Madoff Employees Knowingly Aided Swindle of Clients’ Billions
articles.snippet: A federal jury in Manhatttan has found five associates of the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff guilty on 31 counts of aiding one of the largest Ponzi schemes in history.
articles.abstract: A federal jury in Manhatttan has found five associates of the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff guilty on 31 counts of aiding one of the largest Ponzi schemes in history.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:13 p.m. | A federal jury on Monday found five associates of the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff guilty of 31 counts of aiding one of the largest Ponzi schemes in history.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and DIANA B. HENRIQUES

articles.headline: Insurers Push to Enroll People as Health Care Deadline Nears
articles.snippet: Insurers are hosting events and activities to try to attract hard-to-reach groups and people who had trouble enrolling on their own.
articles.abstract: Insurers are hosting events and activities to try to attract hard-to-reach groups and people who had trouble enrolling on their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s last call for health insurance.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: Freelancers Piece Together a Living in the Temp Economy
articles.snippet: A Las Vegas entertainer who works a variety of jobs finds she must reinvent herself.
articles.abstract: A Las Vegas entertainer who works a variety of jobs finds she must reinvent herself.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The photos spread out on a coffee table tell the story of a career. In one, a woman wears a fairy costume and rides a flying horse. In another, the woman lounges on a desert rock at sunrise, in a gold bikini draped with red silk. In a third, she wears an Uncle Sam outfit and poses on three-foot stilts.

articles.headline: Sweet Smell of Money for Plumbers
articles.snippet: While the hours are long and the job can be smelly, fixing pipes and unclogging drains yields six-figure incomes and steady work for many.
articles.abstract: While the hours are long and the job can be smelly, fixing pipes and unclogging drains yields six-figure incomes and steady work for many.
articles.lead_paragraph: While working underneath a house, Joseph Rosenblum, a plumber in training in northwest Arkansas, confronted a skunk and discovered a talent that he previously hadn’t been aware of: crawling very quickly.

articles.headline: Hurt in Crisis, TPG Pursues Smaller Deals
articles.snippet: The private equity firm is taking a new approach, moving beyond the gigantic acquisitions and, instead, looking more at buying minority stakes.
articles.abstract: The private equity firm is taking a new approach, moving beyond the gigantic acquisitions and, instead, looking more at buying minority stakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the financial crisis erupted in 2008, TPG suffered more than most private equity firms, having invested in three of that era’s most troubled deals.
articles.byline: By William Alden and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: A Question of What’s a Reasonable Reward
articles.snippet: A money manager claims Coca-Cola allocated as much as $24 billion toward stock-based rewards for its senior people.
articles.abstract: A money manager claims Coca-Cola allocated as much as $24 billion toward stock-based rewards for its senior people.
articles.lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Coca-Cola sent out its annual report and proxy statement to shareholders.

articles.headline: Obama to Call for End to N.S.A.’s Bulk Data Collection
articles.snippet: Under the administration’s proposal, the government would obtain individual orders from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court to obtain only records linked to phone numbers a judge agrees are likely tied to terrorism.
articles.abstract: Under the administration’s proposal, the government would obtain individual orders from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court to obtain only records linked to phone numbers a judge agrees are likely tied to terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is preparing to unveil a legislative proposal for a far-reaching overhaul of the National Security Agency’s once-secret bulk phone records program in a way that — if approved by Congress — would end the aspect that has most alarmed privacy advocates since its existence was leaked last year, according to senior administration officials.

articles.headline: General Motors Misled Grieving Families on a Lethal Flaw
articles.snippet: Despite a 2009 meeting confirming a defect in the Chevrolet Cobalt’s ignition switch, General Motors told accident victims’ families it lacked enough evidence of the issue.
articles.abstract: Despite a 2009 meeting confirming a defect in the Chevrolet Cobalt’s ignition switch, General Motors told accident victims’ families it lacked enough evidence of the issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was nearly five years ago that any doubts were laid to rest among engineers at General Motors about a dangerous and faulty ignition switch. At a meeting on May 15, 2009, they learned that data in the black boxes of Chevrolet Cobalts confirmed a potentially fatal defect existed in hundreds of thousands of cars.
articles.byline: By Hilary Stout, Bill Vlasic, Danielle Ivory and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: Car Companies Take Expertise in Battery Power Beyond the Garage
articles.snippet: Honda and other automakers are using car batteries to store solar electricity to use not just in cars, but in homes, too.
articles.abstract: Honda and other automakers are using car batteries to store solar electricity to use not just in cars, but in homes, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVIS, Calif. — As more homeowners generate their own electricity from solar panels, they still need power from a utility after the sun goes down.

articles.headline: A Likely Heir Is Leaving JPMorgan Chase
articles.snippet: The exit of a top banker shows how how easy it is for powerful private equity firms with less regulatory burdens to poach executives from big banks.
articles.abstract: The exit of a top banker shows how how easy it is for powerful private equity firms with less regulatory burdens to poach executives from big banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:51 p.m. | The surprise departure of a top JPMorgan Chase executive for a giant private equity firm underscores how financial regulations are forcing a shift in the balance of power on Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: In Ocean of Mud, a Plea: Leave Me and Find My Wife
articles.snippet: Officials said that they recovered two more bodies from a landslide in Washington and believe they have located another eight in the debris, bringing the official death toll to 16, with the possibility of 24 dead.
articles.abstract: Officials said that they recovered two more bodies from a landslide in Washington and believe they have located another eight in the debris, bringing the official death toll to 16, with the possibility of 24 dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSO, Wash. — This was how last Saturday morning began for Linda McPherson, 68, and her husband, Gary, 78, better known as Mac: They were in their twinned reclining chairs in the living room easing into the day when, without warning, at a few minutes before 11 a.m., their world and everything around them was shattered.
articles.byline: By Kirk Johnson, Ian Lovett and Alan Blinder
